question: If I target an adjacent enemy already sharing a location with Abaddon Succubus, does it still take 2 damage and heal me 2?
answer: Yes!

question: If the targeted minion takes less than 2 damage (or no damage at all), do I still heal 2?
answer: Yes!

question: Does Abundance apply to my opponent's sites as well?
answer: Yes, they will get the benefit as well, if your Abundance affects their sites!

question: When do I get this extra mana?
answer: Mana is added to a player's mana pool during their Start Phase, or when a site enters the realm under their control. So, any sites already in play won't get the extra mana until the start of your next turn. But, if you play Abundance and then play a site into Abundance's area of effect, the newly played site will generate extra mana immediately. Also, if you start your turn with a site in Abundance, and then during your Main Phase the site is no longer in Abundance (e.g. Cloud City moving away, Scorched Earth, etc.), you don't lose the mana that you gained during your Start Phase.

question: How much mana is generated by playing an Ordinary Tower (e.g. Lone Tower) into Abundance's effect?
answer: 3 mana, because 1 (a site entering the realm under your control) + 1 (Abundance) + 1 (Genesis effect) = 3.

question: Can I choose different squares for the damage?
answer: Yes.

question: Is the damage dealt simultaneously?
answer: Yes. For example, if you have a 5 power Monster, it will deal 1+1+1+1+1, all simultaneously. If you try dealing it to a warded unit, the Ward will prevent all of it. If your opponent has Shield Maidens nearby, each damage will be reduced. If you have Panpipes of Pnom, it will be 2+2+2+2+2 damage instead.

question: What does 'cards or allies' mean?
answer: Cards in their hand, or allies in the realm.

question: What does 'shuffle if needed' mean?
answer: If you searched your spellbook, shuffle it. If you end up summoning the extra Illusionist from your hand or cemetery, you may still have searched your spellbook if you wanted.

question: Does this ability work whenever Adtonitum moves, even if it's my opponent's turn?
answer: Yes, this is a triggered ability, which can trigger on your opponent's turn as well, if Adtonitum moves.

question: Does this need to be carried to have an effect?
answer: Yes, since 'you' or 'your' refers to the controller of the artifact, and carriable artifacts must be carried to be controlled.

question: Must spells cast by the Omphalos match its elements?
answer: Yes. Any spell the Omphalos casts much match at least one of its elements.

question: Does my avatar still take the damage, but I just don't lose the game?
answer: Correct! Damage is still dealt to your avatar for effects that care about dealing damage. You just don't lose the game as a result!

question: When does this artifact provide mana?
answer: When it enters the realm, and at the start of its controller's turn.

question: If a warded Angel Ascendant fights another minion, the ward will break when the strike happens. So does Angel Ascendant strike for 2 or 3?
answer: It will strike for 3 (with the +1 power from Ward). If the opposing minion somehow struck first (perhaps via a Lance), then the ward would indeed break first and then the Angel Ascendant would only strike back for 2.

question: If I cast a Magic as a Spirit minion, will Orb of Ba'al Berith copy it?
answer: Good try, but no. You're casting it as a minion, so the game sees it as a Minion spell, not a Magic spell.

question: If I increase or decrease the cost of a magic while I cast it as a Spirit minion, how much power will it have in the realm?
answer: Use the printed cost of the magic as its power, regardless of how much mana you actually spent to cast it. Note that magics with X as their cost work appropriately, based on the unmodified cost of the spell when you cast it.

question: If I cast a magic with X as its cost (e.g. Arcane Barrage) as a Spirit minion, will the minion retain the correct power?
answer: Yes, because of the golden rule. If you pay 7 mana for your Arcane Barrage Spirit minion, it will have 7 power while in the realm.

question: If Selfsame Simulacrum is summoned as a basic copy of an animated magic, what happens?
answer: 'Basic copy' refers to the printed characteristics of the card, which means Selfsame will try to become a magic. But magics cannot exist in the realm, so Selfsame Simulacrum would immediately go to the cemetery and there would be no effect of the magic. Sorry!

question: If I cast a magic as a Spirit minion, do I still get the effect of the magic?
answer: No. Treat the textbox of the magic as entirely blank, though it retains its elements and rarity. For example, if you cast Craterize as Spirit minion, you do not need to discard a site as an additional cost, and it will be summoned as an 8 power, Elite earth minion.

question: If there are multiple Apostles of Thamariel in play, do I need to track which Apostles go with which Angels?
answer: Yes!

question: When does this artifact provide mana?
answer: When it enters the realm, and at the start of its controller's turn.

question: Do you still need to meet threshold requirements when using its ability?
answer: Yes, since you're still casting it (and not summoning it directly).

question: If Michael cannot take a step, does he still get to strike?
answer: Yes, but you must declare a legal step if you can, using the normal lookahead rules described in 'Range of Motion.'

question: When I cast one of the banished spells, is that placed back in the cemetery?
answer: No. There's no way back from being banished, which overrides the part of resolution that would place the card in the cemetery.

question: When I use the Archimago's ability to banish 3 magic spells and cast 1, do I still have to pay mana and meet threshold?
answer: Yes.

question: When using this ability, must the Archimago be the caster?
answer: No, any of your spellcasters can cast the copied spell.

question: What happens if I pay the cost of banishing three spells, but I cannot actually cast any of those three?
answer: If you cannot cast any of those three spells, they remain banished and nothing else happens. You did not cast a spell. (If you can cast one of the three, you must.)

question: Can I use this ability to cast Valor or Dodge Roll?
answer: No, because the Archimago's ability is an activated ability, which you can only use during your Main Phase when nothing is on the Storyline.

question: If the Army moves through many locations (e.g. Grapple Shot, Seven-league Boots), does it leave many Skeletons behind?
answer: Yes! Leave a Skeleton behind each time the Army enters a new location (or takes damage).

question: What is 'fire damage' ?
answer: 'Fire damage' is any damage from a fire source, such as a fire minion (including strikes), a fire site, or a fire spell. Morgana le Fay casting Lightning Bolt is not fire damage, since Lightning Bolt is an air spell. Apprentice Wizard casting Firebolts is fire damage because Firebolts is a fire spell (and in fact would be 3 separate instances of fire damage). Anyone casting Grapple Shot that sends a minion into the Phoenix will look at the minion making the strike; if it's a fire minion, it's fire damage. If the Phoenix attacks and there are multiple defenders, each defending fire minion that strikes it counts as a separate source of fire damage.

question: For purposes of cards that care about the mana cost of spells, what is the mana cost of a spell with X?
answer: If you cast the spell, the mana cost is X. For example, if you cast it for 2 mana, then Immortal Throne would see it as a 2 cost spell. But, if you aren't casting the spell and it's simply in your hand, spellbook, etc., then X is 0 until you actually cast it.

question: Can you play Rift Valley into an area affected by Atlantean Fate?
answer: Yes, since Atlantean Fate only affects the site once it's already in play, and Rift Valley modifies how it's played in the first place.

question: If one of the sites it occupies is an Ordinary water site, are minions and artifacts there still submerged?
answer: Yes. It's still affected by the aura, but that effect doesn't do anything to Ordinary sites, other than the Genesis ability.

question: What does 'normal size' mean?
answer: Anything that occupies exactly 1 location.

question: Does this carry along oversized units or auras that occupy more than one square?
answer: No.

question: What does 'your body of water' mean?
answer: The body of water (if any) that your Avatar currently occupies. If the Avatar isn't in any body of water, the ability won't function. (They're a fish out of water!)

question: Can you choose an existing water site?
answer: Yes.

question: Am I required to summon these units burrowed?
answer: Yes. You can and you must.

question: Do they tap when they unburrow?
answer: No.

question: Can I target my opponent's minion(s) with Backstab?
answer: Yes (but remember the spellcaster must be in the same region as all the targets).

question: If a minion has voidwalk and is in the void, could Backstab move it to an adjacent site to strike a tapped minion there?
answer: No. Your spellcaster must target both minions (which are in different regions), but that's impossible since you pick a single location the spellcaster occupies for casting a spell. You can only target minions in the region where the spell is being cast. See '((Casting Spells))' for more details.

question: Is the damage resolved one at a time, after each hit?
answer: Yes! Resolve the damage (and any deathrites) from the first hit, then bounce for the second hit, resolving that damage, then bounce and resolve the third hit.

question: Can I hit the caster or other allies with this?
answer: At the first location of the projectile's path, it cannot hit allies or the caster, even if it hits an enemy there first. If the Ball Lightning leaves the first location, it could bounce back and hit allies or the caster later in its path.

question: After bouncing off a unit, does the ball hit them again immediately since they are both at the same starting location?
answer: No. But the ball can hit other units at that location after changing direction, bouncing back and forth.

question: If I choose to do 2 damage at one location, do I need to do damage at all the locations in that cardinal direction?
answer: Yes. If you choose to resolve this effect, you must deal 2 damage to one unit at each other location in the chosen direction.

question: If the Battlemage attacks and kills two enemies in a single fight (if my opponent chose to include multiple defenders), does the Battlemage draw two cards?
answer: Yes.

question: If the Battlemage activates the 'Move and Attack' ability, doesn't actually attack, and then is intercepted, does that count as 'attacking' the intercepting unit?
answer: No. An interception does not cause an 'attack,' and instead is merely a fight between the unit that used 'Move and Attack' and the unit that intercepted.

question: If I declare an attack against one target, but then a different enemy defends, does that satisfy this ability?
answer: Yes. An attack was made, and then a minion was killed. As long as your attacking unit used the Move and Attack ability and then got kill credit, this ability is satisfied.

question: If the Battlemage with a Flaming Sword attacks one enemy, and then another enemy dies as a result of the Flaming Sword, does the Battlemage get to draw a card?
answer: Yes. An attack was made, and then a minion was killed. As long as your attacking unit used the Move and Attack ability and then got kill credit, this ability triggers.

question: What happens when a minion carries another minion that's carrying a minion?
answer: Only the minions you're directly carrying count against your limit. Have fun at the carnival!

question: If my opponent plays an effect that tries to cancel Bedrock in some way (e.g. Atlantean Fate, Smokestacks of Gnaak, etc.), what happens?
answer: Bedrock wins, and is not modified in any way.

question: Does this effect target the minion?
answer: No! Therefore, the banished minion can be in a different region and/or have Stealth.

question: What if there was more than one killer last turn?
answer: Bitter Departed may teleport to any one of the killers to strike it.

question: How do I resolve this effect?
answer: The first eight times the cat would die, it doesn't instead. Track it in some reasonable way. If it gains a deathrite, it does not trigger on the first eight lives, since it doesn't actually die. If the cat is moved to an inhospitable location, e.g. underground or underwater, the game will notice and try to kill it along with any other minions who should die. The other minion's deathrite effects will resolve first, and they'll go to the cemetery. Then the game will notice the cat should die, and continue trying to kill it until it's actually dead and goes to the cemetery.

question: When I put the cards on the bottom of my spellbook, do the searched cards get shuffled?
answer: Yes.

question: Are these family cards of Castle Servants, Common Cottagers, Blacksmith Family, and Fisherman's Family considered Air, Earth, Fire, and Water spells, respectively?
answer: Yes. You can see the spell's colored frame matches those elements, so Castle Servants is an Air spell, Common Cottagers is an Earth spell, Blacksmith Family is a Fire spell, and Fisherman's Family is a Water Spell.

question: How do I resolve this ability?
answer: Fully complete the first attack, including deathrites. Then, Bladedancer must take a step to a different location to be able to attack a new unit (or the same unit if it's oversized and occupies multiple locations). The step cannot be intercepted, but the attack is an actual second attack, following the normal attack sequence.

question: How do I resolve this effect?
answer: Each minion simultaneously deals 1 damage to its site. Then, starting with the active player and then the non-active player, each minion chooses an artifact at it's location to destroy; you must choose an artifact that hasn't been chosen if possible. Then, all the artifacts are simultaneously destroyed. Finally, all minions tap (and won't untap the next time they normally would).

question: How can I tell if a spell or non-basic ability targets something?
answer: It will use the word 'target.'

question: Are random events affected?
answer: No. Something like Lightning Bolt ('Deal 3 damage to a random unit at target location') must target Blasted Oak's location, but then the random result is still determined randomly

question: What happens if you have Kythera Mechanism?
answer: When you target, you must follow Blasted Oak's restrictions, but you can still choose random outcomes of your choice if you have Kythera Mechanism.

question: Does summoning a minion target the location where it's summoned?
answer: No, and therefore Blasted Oak doesn't influence where minions may be summoned.

question: How does this interact with Chain Lightning?
answer: You must target all the units you can that share Blasted Oak's site, spending as much mana as needed to do so. Once you've targeted all those units, you could additionally target other units, if you had sufficient mana. For reference, Chain Lightning reads: Deal 2 damage to target unit nearby. Any number of times, you may spend 2 mana to additionally target a new unit nearby the previous one.

question: What is the proper timing of resolution for this effect?
answer: If the Blazing unit moves and attacks, the proper sequence is to resolve the move, then deal 2 damage at each departed location simultaneously, then resolve the attack.

question: If the Blazing unit moves over the same location multiple times without stopping, how much damage does Blaze do?
answer: Blaze will still only do 2 damage, since a unit is either along the trail, or not. Each time the Blazing unit stops, it creates a separate trail of fire.

question: If the Blazing unit dies, does it deal damage where it died?
answer: No. Though it clearly departed its location, it never 'stops,' which is what causes the flame to cause damage. To 'stop,' a unit needs to move first. (Note that if the Blazing unit somehow died while moving, then Blaze would in fact deal damage when the unit died.)

question: Is this magic damage?
answer: Yes. The source of the damage is the Blaze spell, not the unit.

question: If a Blazing Megamoeba moves, does Blaze do damage?
answer: No, since the Megamoeba still occupies the sites and thus never departed.

question: Does this need to be carried to have an effect?
answer: Yes, since 'you' or 'your' refers to the controller of the artifact, and carriable artifacts must be carried to be controlled.

question: Can a disabled unit Blink?
answer: Yes, this is forced movement, not taking a step themselves.

question: The beta foil version of Blink and Blizzard have their the title, mana cost, and typeline swapped. Is that a misprint?
answer: Yes, this is a misprint. These are not legal for tournament play.

question: The beta foil version of Blink and Blizzard have their the title, mana cost, and typeline swapped. Is that a misprint?
answer: Yes, this is a misprint. These are not legal for tournament play.

question: Do I still need to meet threshold requirements and pay additional costs, e.g. discarding a site for Craterize?
answer: Yes!

question: How does Blood Mana interact with reduced costs?
answer: The same cost you would pay with mana is paid by your life instead.

question: Can I pay more life than I have? What if I'm on death's door?
answer: You cannot pay more life than you have. If you're on death's door, you won't be able to pay any life and Blood Mana won't help you.

question: What happens if the next spell I cast is Twist of Fate?
answer: Let's say your life is 16 and my life is 20. Therefore, you cast Twist of Fate for 4 mana, but instead of mana, you pay 4 life. Your life is now 12 and the magic goes onto the Storyline. The magic resolves, swapping our life totals. My life is now 12 and your life is 20. Tricky!

question: How do I resolve this effect?
answer: You may simultaneously pick up from all adjacent locations. Anything picked up is forcefully moved to the Bogeyman's location. Once it arrives, it is disabled.

question: What is the proper timing of resolution for this effect?
answer: Non-active player chooses a minion. Active player chooses a minion. Both minions enter the realm simultaneously. Then, the non-active player resolves any triggered abilities (like genesis), and finally the active player resolves their triggered abilities.

question: If my magic targets my allied minion, does that qualify as 'chooses' for the Book of Blessing?
answer: Yes!

question: Does the swallowed minion untap? Is it still in the realm? Can it be attacked?
answer: Yes.

question: If the swallowed minion is moved away somehow, does it lose Disabled?
answer: Yes.

question: How does this effect resolve?
answer: 'Access' occurs if a card would leave the collection or cemetery zone. You may still freely look at your collection and cemetery, and add cards to them. For example, Archimago must pay (2) to use his ability. Similarly, Deathspeaker must pay (2) to use his ability. If an effect is resolving (and not paying a cost like Archimago or Deathspeaker), you may choose not to pay the (2) and have that part of the effect fail. For example, Feast for Crows may search the other zones and simply not remove any spells from cemetery.

question: Do I get the cards immediately when my minion carrying the treasure moves to the surface, even in the middle of something else (like defending or attacking) ?
answer: Yes! As soon as your unit is on the surface, you resolve the treasure effect.

question: Do I still need to meet threshold and summoning requirements when I cast the spell?
answer: Yes. E.g. It must still be cast to your own site.

question: What does it mean to 'lock' a minion here, and how does the Cage work?
answer: All minions with 2 or less power are teleported to the Cage and are carried by it. If the Cage moves, the carried minions move with it. While locked in the cage, the minions remain tapped and disabled. If a minion is somehow no longer carried by the Cage, it is free and no longer disabled. If a minion somehow becomes carried by the Cage (e.g. Swap), it is tapped and disabled.

question: If Captain Baldassare attacks a 3 power minion, killing it but also dying in the process, does the Captain have time to use their ability before they die?
answer: Yes, by a long shot! In fact, Captain Baldassare's trigger happens as soon as the attack is resolving, even before strikes are made. The trigger for Captain's ability and the Captain dying aren't in the same window of time. The ability triggers first.

question: If Castle Haunt is summoned to a void, e.g. Lucid Dreamers, how does its ability apply?
answer: It was never summoned to a site, so it's free to roam around the realm! (Unless it was summoned to The Void site, in which case its restriction applies normally!)

question: If Castle Haunt leaves its summoning site and doesn't immediately die, what happens?
answer: It's free to roam around the realm! This could happen because the Castle Haunt is silenced or disabled as soon as it leaves its summoning site, or because it survives via a Ward upon leaving. If it ever returns to its summoning site, its ability will apply again if it tries to leave again.

question: Are these family cards of Castle Servants, Common Cottagers, Blacksmith Family, and Fisherman's Family considered Air, Earth, Fire, and Water spells, respectively?
answer: Yes. You can see the spell's colored frame matches those elements, so Castle Servants is an Air spell, Common Cottagers is an Earth spell, Blacksmith Family is a Fire spell, and Fisherman's Family is a Water Spell.

question: What does 'your location' mean?
answer: In this case, 'your location' means 'a location that your avatar occupies.'

question: What does 'can't move itself away' mean?
answer: Cerberus can't choose to move to a location that is farther from your avatar than its current location. (Count distance using steps that Cerberus would take using its own modes of movement, e.g. Airborne if it gained it somehow.)

question: If your avatar occupies a site you don't control, can you summon Cerberus there?
answer: No. The first sentence is an additional restriction on summoning.

question: How does Cerberus in Chains automatically follow you?
answer: Whenever your avatar enters a new location, Cerberus in Chains teleports to that location.

question: Do I pay all the costs and choose all the targets when the spell is cast?
answer: Yes.

question: Does the damage resolve sequentially or simultaneously?
answer: All targets take the damage simultaneously.

question: Can I chain the lightning from target A to target B back to target A?
answer: No, that's not what 'new' means. You can only choose new targets that haven't already been targeted by the spell.

question: Can additional targets be in different regions (as long as they're nearby the previous target)?
answer: No. Being nearby the previous target is an additional targeting restriction, not a loosening of the targeting rules, so all targets must be in the same region as the caster.

question: Does the minion teleport to the location where it lands?
answer: Yes. It teleports to the surface of the site (or void) where it lands.

question: What if the minion lands in the void?
answer: It deals no damage (even to itself). Since it's now in the void, it is banished (unless it has Voidwalk).

question: What if the minion lands atop two or more sites?
answer: It lands on only a single site, which is the one that it most fully overlaps.

question: What if I'm using Chaos Twister on a token? Or a really expensive card with triple sleeves?
answer: Feel free to use a stand-in.

question: Does the minion continue to carry whatever it was carrying?
answer: Yes.

question: How should I resolve this card in a tournament setting?
answer: This card as-written represents part of our design philosophy for Sorcery. Apply the birthday candle rule, which is that you must blow the card off your hand in a single breath; if you do not, then the effect fails. If the card falls prior to starting to blow, replace it on your hand. Once you start blowing, if the card falls due to anything other than blowing (e.g. hand movement), the effect fails. Call a judge before resolving this card if you're worried, but please be cool and apply the golden rule!

question: What if the minion doesn't land in the grid at all?
answer: The teleportation effect doesn't happen and it deals no damage.

question: Where does the copied spell come from?
answer: It's a copy, which is a token, so you have unlimited copies, as needed. It doesn't come from your hand or your deck or anywhere else. It's a token!

question: If I have Kythera Mechanism and keep 'randomly' choosing Chaoswish, can I cast infinite spells?
answer: Specify the number of times you cast Chaoswish, and then proceed with the game. Your opponent will have the chance to copy Chaoswish that number of times!

question: How do I generate a random spell?
answer: Click the button on this page!

question: Once I cast a random spell, how do I track it during the game?
answer: Be prepared with index cards + pencil, or some other way to track what gets copied! Note that a copy is a token, so once it leaves the realm, it's banished per normal token rules. Magics (and any other copy) won't end up in the cemetery.

question: What happens if the random spell cannot be cast, e.g. no valid target?
answer: The spell is not cast, and the next player may copy Chaoswish.

question: What if the random spell has additional costs, e.g. Craterize?
answer: When you cast '((for free)),' you don't pay any additional costs. Have fun!

question: Must I choose which of my spellcasters is casting the spell before I know what it is?
answer: Yes.

question: What happens if I play Courtesan Thaïs and then immediately play Chaoswish on the same turn?
answer: It's still your turn, so your opponent still controls their own choices. They can freely choose to copy Chaoswish or not. On the other hand, if you cast Courtesan Thaïs first, then on your opponent's turn (which you're controlling) you see that they have Chaoswish in hand and you cast it for them, you can keep copying Chaoswish as long as you want; you will decide for yourself and you will decide for them (since you're controlling their turn).

question: If my opponent and I keep deciding to copy Chaoswish, what happens?
answer: You have a lot of fun? In a tournament setting, you'll probably hit the round time limit eventually.

question: Must spells cast by the Omphalos match its elements?
answer: Yes. Any spell the Omphalos casts much match at least one of its elements.

question: Is the site played adjacent to the Clay Golem, superseding normal site placement rules?
answer: Yes!

question: Does this carry along oversized minions or auras that occupy more than one square?
answer: No. If an oversized minion is now occupying the void, it will be banished. (Megamoeba will still move with Cloud City.)

question: Does this carry along oversized units or auras that occupy more than one square?
answer: No.

question: Are these family cards of Castle Servants, Common Cottagers, Blacksmith Family, and Fisherman's Family considered Air, Earth, Fire, and Water spells, respectively?
answer: Yes. You can see the spell's colored frame matches those elements, so Castle Servants is an Air spell, Common Cottagers is an Earth spell, Blacksmith Family is a Fire spell, and Fisherman's Family is a Water Spell.

question: Does Cone of Flame extend across multiple regions?
answer: No, all affected locations must be in the same region as the caster. By default, the damage grid is restricted to the caster's region. If the caster occupies multiple regions (e.g. a oversized unit), pick a single region where you're casting the spell.

question: All the empty boxes are void and the letters are sites. If the spell is cast from the surface of X, is Z affected?
answer: Yes, because it's the same region as the spell effect, even though it's separated by void.

question: If I control Rubble, can my opponent still play a site there?
answer: Yes, but it might only feed the worm.

question: Does 'has no power here' mean Evil units here have zero power?
answer: Yes. Note that when you strike, you determine your power first, then you determine how much damage you deal. So an Evil minion with a Lance would still strike a unit for 1 damage, because it has 0 power and then gets +1 damage from the Lance. See '((Damage))' for more details.

question: How do I resolve this effect?
answer: Deal face up, one at a time, taking minions from any cemetery. You choose which minions you deal to each site. The dead minions do not actually 'enter' the realm with this effect. Then, damage is dealt simultaneously.

question: Does the type of my minions change everywhere, or just in the realm?
answer: Everywhere!

question: Does this ability completely replace their normal type, or simply add a new type?
answer: It adds an additional type. For example, your Mortals are Undead and Mortals and would still be silenced by Bower of Bliss. As another example, your Beasts are Monsters and Beasts, so you would still get the discount from a Pond.

question: What does it mean for one player to be controlled by another player?
answer: If you control a player, you see all their cards and make all decisions for them. You still must make legal choices for them. For example, you still cannot force their minion to move into the void (without Voidwalk) or attack themselves.

question: What happens if there are multiple copies of Courtesan Thaïs played, overlapping each other?
answer: The effects can overlap. They do not add additional turns of control beyond what's specified by card text. For example, Turn 1: Player A plays Courtesan 1. Turn 2: Player B is controlled by Player A due to Courtesan 1's effect, and plays Courtesan 2. Turn 3: Player A is controlled by Player B due to Courtesan 1's effect and Courtesan 2's effect. Turn 4: Player B is controlled by Player A due to Courtesan 2's effect.

question: The beta foil version has 1 fire threshold and the normal version has 2 fire threshold. Which is correct?
answer: The normal version is correct. You still need 2 fire affinity to cast this minion.

question: What happens if my turn is skipped via Vaults of Zul and Courtesan Thaïs is affecting me?
answer: If a turn is skipped then there's no actual turn, which means that part of Courtesan Thaïs's effect would wait for that player's next actual turn.

question: When I control my opponent's turn, can I force them to concede?
answer: No. Stop it.

question: Do I still need to meet threshold and summoning requirements when I cast the spell?
answer: Yes. It must be cast during your main phase, to your own site, etc. It's an otherwise normal minion spell being cast, except that it's coming from the top of your library instead of your hand, and costs (1) less.

question: Is the ability to look at my top spell a passive abililty?
answer: Yes. You may look any time on your turn, including during your Start Phase and End Phase.

question: Do I have to choose 'above' or 'below,' or does it damage both automatically?
answer: There is a giant meteor landing in the realm! It damages both above and ((below)) - surface, underwater, and underground!

question: All the empty boxes are void and the letters are sites. If the spell is cast from the surface of X, is Z affected?
answer: Yes, because it's the same region as the spell effect, even though it's separated by void.

question: Can Crave Golem attack itself?
answer: No, per normal attack restrictions (which the Crave Golem respects).

question: Does it use normal targeting rules when attacking?
answer: Yes, except that it may attack other allied minions if they happen to be the chosen target. It still cannot attack Airborne or Stealth units unless it gains a special ability that allows it to do so.

question: How do I properly resolve this ability?
answer: First, identify all the minions that Crave Golem ))can attack(( within its range of motion. If there are one or more such minions: Randomly pick one, then move (if needed), and attack it. This counts as a normal attack and may be defended. For example, if there's one adjacent minion with Airborne and another without Airborne, it will attack the non-Airborne minion 100% of the time (unless Crave Golem somehow gained Airborne). If there are no such minions: Imagine the Crave Golem had unlimited movement. Are there any minions it could attack now? If not, it doesn't move and the ability is over. If so, take one step toward the minion that requires the fewest Crave Golem steps to reach. (Crave Golem's controller's choice if tied.) This movement cannot be intercepted.

question: Does it tap to take a step or attack?
answer: No.

question: When it attacks, does the targeted unit strike back?
answer: Yes.

question: When it attacks, do normal combat rules apply with defending?
answer: Yes.

question: If I double twice, is it multiplied by 4?
answer: Yes.

question: If I sacrifice Crown Prince (e.g. Moon Clan Werewolf, Cauldron Crones, etc.), does its deathrite still trigger?
answer: Yes! When you sacrifice something, it dies, and thus triggers deathrite.

question: The term 'summon' means 'enter the realm.' So, does that mean I can play minions here for free?
answer: No. This effect simply provides additional locations where you may summon your earth minions.

question: Must spells cast by the Omphalos match its elements?
answer: Yes. Any spell the Omphalos casts much match at least one of its elements.

question: What path can I choose when resolving this ability?
answer: See ((Moving to a Specific Location Via a Special Ability or Magic)) in the Codex.

question: Can I rotate the cross?
answer: Yes.

question: Must the cross be entirely within the realm?
answer: Yes. Evil can cower safely in the corners!

question: Does this affect multiple regions, such as the void and subsurface as well?
answer: Yes! The card text uses 'affected squares,' which include surface, subsurface, and void.

question: How do I properly resolve the banish and damage effects?
answer: Banish Evil minions first, resolving effects (if any) as a result of their banishment. Then, damage all units occupying those five squares.

question: Can I modify the cost of (5)?
answer: Yes! If you have Philosopher's Stone and you're playing as Harbinger, you could perhaps cast minions for a mere (3)!

question: Does it kill minions everywhere in the realm, even in the void or underground or underwater?
answer: Yes.

question: At Death's Door, does the Deathspeaker need to meet the threshold requirements?
answer: Yes. Only the casting cost is reduced to (0).

question: Can any of my spellcasters cast a spell and still benefit from my avatar's ability?
answer: Yes! As long as you control the spellcaster, the game sees it as a spell '((you))' cast, meaning the player.

question: When using the Deathspeaker's ability, do I trigger Deathrite effects (perhaps because the minion is on The Geistwood)?
answer: Normally no, because Deathrite only triggers when the minion dies, and the Deathspeaker's ability banishes the minion. But, if you somehow kill the minion at the same time it enters the realm (e.g. Bottomless Pit), then Deathrite would trigger. The token dies because of Bottomless Pit (interrupting the Deathspeaker's ability), Deathrite resolves, then the token copy is banished like all tokens when it dies.

question: How does this ability resolve, in detail?
answer: You cast the minion spell. Pay mana, meet threshold, banish it from the cemetery, identify where it will be summoned. The minion enters the the realm. (It is a copy of the banished minion.) 'Enter the ))realm((' effects trigger and resolve. These include: Genesis abilities. Effects like Wayfaring Pilgrim, Giant Shark, Mariner's Curse, Bottomless Pit, etc. See '((Simultaneous Triggers))' in the Codex for more details. The minion is banished. The intent is that the Deathspeaker can speak to the dead, invoke their abilities, and then release them into the afterlife (whatever that may be). See also '((Splitting Events on the Storyline))' and the example with Tawny plus a site's genesis. The Deathspeaker's ability is analogous, since the minion will enter, splitting the Deathspeaker's ability on the Storyline, the genesis ability will resolve (along with any other triggered abilities based on a minion entering the ))realm((), then it will get banished.

question: When using the Deathspeaker's ability, do Genesis abilities trigger before the banishing effect?
answer: Yes, because events on the storyline are split up when a card enters the realm. See the '((Splitting Events on the Storyline))' codex entry for more details.

question: Can I cast minions from my opponent's cemetery?
answer: Yes. You control it when it enters the realm, and then it gets banished.

question: What if my current life is higher than my maximum life after this effect resolves?
answer: Your current life is immediately reduced to your maximum life.

question: If an avatar has an odd maximum life, do they round down after halving it?
answer: Yes.

question: What is all of the small text on this card?!
answer: Don't tell me you entered into a contract with a Demon without reading the fine print! The smaller text is all of the rules and stipulations for the casting of this spell!

question: What is 'lower' rarity?
answer: The order of rarities (from highest to lowest) is: Unique, Elite, Exceptional, and Ordinary. For example, if you control an Exceptional Demon, you could search for an Exceptional or Ordinary spell.

question: Does this count as healing?
answer: No, this removes Death's Door and then sets your life to 1.

question: What if I cast this while my life is higher than 1?
answer: You set your life to 1.

question: If I break two allied Wards to increase the damage, will it be three instances of 1 damage each, or 3 damage once?
answer: Three damage once.

question: If Dodge Roll's mana cost is increased (e.g. Maddening Bells), can you cast it on your opponent's turn?
answer: No, because you don't have any mana available on your opponent's turn.

question: If a minion here is attacked what happens?
answer: It's not possible to declare an attack against a minion here. If you attack an avatar here and a minion defends, the minion becomes a legal target, per the Defend rules.

question: Does this site protect minions from cards with the word 'attack' in their name, like Leap Attack or Spin Attack?
answer: No. Dome of Osiros only prevents 'attacks' from the Move and Attack basic ability, or other card text that uses the word 'attack' (e.g. Crave Golem).

question: When counting 'each unit,' do I include all adjacent squares?
answer: Yes! Count any unit in any square adjacent to the summoning square (including the summoning square itself). Each unit counts once, regardless of how many adjacent squares it occupies.

question: When do I choose my set aside Dragon? Can it change during a tournament?
answer: You must select your set aside Dragon 'before setup,' which means during deckbuilding. You cannot change it during a tournament. The Dragonlord is loyal to his champion and would not be so fickle!

question: Can my spellbook include a copy of my set aside Unique Dragon?
answer: Yes! The set aside Dragon is intended as a rules reference for both players. You may use a suitable substitute for the set aside Dragon, if needed.

question: When the Dragonlord gains the abilities of the set aside Dragon, does the Dragonlord gain its power as well?
answer: No, power is a characteristic, not an ability. The Dragonlord will only gain the abilities printed in the text box.

question: Can the Dragonlord gain Stealth?
answer: No. Avatars cannot gain Stealth.

question: If the Dragonlord gains Voidwalk, Burrowing, or Submerge, may it enter other regions?
answer: No. Avatars cannot enter any region other than the surface.

question: If the Dragonlord gains Ignis Rex's ability, is that considered fire damage? Same question for Adtonitum and air damage?
answer: Yes! If the Dragonlord gains Ignis Rex's ability and then discards a fire card, the Dragonlord will deal fire damage. Same answer for Adtonitum and air damage.

question: What does 'attack out of this site' mean?
answer: Take exactly one step away from the site, then attack. It doesn't matter if the unit took steps before entering the Dread Thicket, merely that they take exactly one step away from the Thicket and then attack.

question: Can I cast this on my Avatar, since they are a spellcaster?
answer: Your avatar can't be disabled per their characteristics. Thus, they won't be able to go to sleep, and therefore won't be able to wake up. If you cast this on your Avatar, it will have no effect.

question: Can Floodplain still flood a site affected by Drought?
answer: Yes. See '((Example - Flood vs. Drought))' in the codex.

question: How do Drought and Flood interact?
answer: See '((Example - Flood vs. Drought))' in the codex.

question: Does the Druid's flip side ability work with Poisonous Dagger?
answer: No. The site itself gains the ability and is doing the damage.

question: Can the Druid's flip side ability give the Druid kill credit?
answer: No. Only units can get kill credit, and the site is source of the damage. The triggered ability is the site's ability, not the Druid's. See the '((kill credit))' codex entry for more details.

question: If a site loses its abilities, does the Druid's flip side ability still apply? Can this affect Bedrock?
answer: No. The Druid grants an ability to the site. If the site is silenced (or can't be modified in the case of Bedrock), then it loses the ability and will not deal damage.

question: How does this ability impact my collection?
answer: You may include any cards you wish in your collection, following normal deckbuilding rules. If you have 0 copies of a unique card in your deck, you may include 1 ))copy(( in your collection. If you have 2 copies of a unique card in your deck, you cannot include any copies in your collection.

question: If I have Dwarven Digging Team in play, can I choose to summon minions underground without a printed Burrowing ability?
answer: No. The units don't gain Burrowing until they're at nearby sites, and you must choose the summoning location when you cast the spell. When you cast the minion spell, it doesn't have burrowing yet, and thus you cannot pick an underground location.

question: What does 'normal size' mean?
answer: Anything that occupies exactly 1 location.

question: Does this carry along oversized units or auras that occupy more than one square?
answer: No.

question: If the 2x2 area includes some sites and some void, can you rearrange the sites into the void squares?
answer: No. You can rearrange sites with other sites as you wish, but the void squares must remain the same.

question: Does diagonal movement include 'sideways' movement?
answer: No.

question: What happens if Edge of the World's ability is lost (e.g. Smokestacks of Gnaak), then Edge of the World gets surrounded by sites, then its ability is regained (e.g. Smokestacks of Gnaak moves away)?
answer: In this rare case, Edge of the World would destroy itself.

question: What happens if an effect causes edge of the world to not be adjacent to the void?
answer:
The effect does not resolve. Examples:
If you try to move Cloud City to the only void square adjacent to Edge of the World, Cloud City won't move.
If you try to play a site from your hand, it won't work and your site will remain in your hand.
If you use Earthquake to rearrange sites in a way that Edge of the World isn't adjacent to void, the entire rearrangement fails (and then you still try to burrow.)
If you have two Magellan Globes in play at the same location and they're the only thing keeping Edge of the World adjacent to void and they are Dispelled, one is destroyed and other isn't.

question: Turning auras into minions!? Is this real?
answer: Yes, indeed. Enchantress is a very versatile Avatar, and one that twists the rules to create very interesting games. Be sure to check these FAQs as well as the auras you're looking to animate. Since many auras occupy a 2x2 area in the realm, you may want to learn about oversized units as well.

question: What is the proper timing of resolution for this effect?
answer: Whenever you cast a spell, before that spell resolves, but after targets are specified. See the 'storyline' entry for more details.

question: Can you animate your opponent's auras?
answer: Yes, as long as you can target them (i.e. they are in the same region as the Enchantress). Your opponent still controls the aura minion.

question: Can any of my spellcasters cast a spell and still benefit from my avatar's ability?
answer: Yes! As long as you control the spellcaster, the game sees it as a spell '((you))' cast, meaning the player.

question: Do animated aura change size?
answer: No.

question: If Magellan Globe is in play and an Oversized unit on the top row moves 'up' one row to wrap around to the bottom, what happens?
answer: Since Magellan Globe is an ongoing effect that connects the top and bottom edges, the oversized unit can occupy 2 locations on the top row and 2 locations on the bottom row. Ensure that game state is clear, using notes as needed.

question: If Polar Explorers or Ruler of Thul are in play and an oversized unit on the top row moves 'up' one row to wrap around to the bottom, what happens?
answer: This ability only allows movement across the borders, not ongoing occupation. Units cannot balance on the edge of the realm and an oversized unit that finds its way there falls to one side or the other. Its controller places it in the closest legal position, controller's choice if tied.

question: If Magellan Globe leaves play when a card is spanning the edge of the realm, what happens?
answer: Units cannot balance on the edge of the realm and an oversized unit that finds its way there falls to one side or the other. Its controller places it in the closest legal position, controller's choice if tied.

question: Does this affect subsurface units, as well as surface?
answer: Yes, since it doesn't say 'atop.' Note that it doesn't affect minions in the void, since the void isn't a site.

question: Do I really have to rip it to pieces?
answer: Please see the golden rule! The point is to actually, literally rip the card up, so it will never be playable again. It is banished after you rip it.

question: How does this work in a tournament, especially in best of 1 games, when I rip this?
answer: See the rules for that specific tournament, but by default the card is playable. Tournament organizers have latitude to set rules for their events, but one reasonable approach is that you use a deck missing one card for the rest of the tournament (and it's legal to do so).

question: If my opponent gains control of my Erik's Curiosa and then they rip it, who gets to pick the card?
answer: They get a card of the controller's choice from the controller's collection (so they get to pick). Hopefully you can still be friends! (They must give you a moment to concede before they rip it.)

question: Does this effect let me break the normal restrictions on deck legality? e.g. duplicate Unique card, or duplicate any site for Pathfinder?
answer: The card limits exist only when the game starts; once the game begins, various effects can change your deck composition. So, yes, you are free to get an extra copy of a Unique card via Erik's Curiosa, as long as the card is actually in your collection.

question: How do I resolve this effect?
answer: When you would use your avatar's ability (or another ability to play sites without restriction), you may choose to play that site from your collection and banish Ersatz Platz.

question: The term 'summon' means 'enter the realm.' So, does that mean I can play minions here for free?
answer: No. This effect simply provides additional locations where you may summon your minions.

question: Does this effect count all wards in the realm, or only ones I control?
answer: It counts all wards in the realm, on any unit or site!

question: If my summoned minion has a genesis effect, does the genesis resolve before the strike?
answer: Yes, resolve the genesis first, including any deathrites. Then, the 'strike each other unit' effect resolves.

question: Are the strikes against other units all simultaneous?
answer: Yes.

question: How does this resolve if I summon an oversized minion?
answer: At least one of the summoning sites must include an affected site. The 'strike each other unit where it lands' effect occurs on one affected site of your choice (that the summoned minion occupies).

question: When you use the ability, what happens to the 'thrown' artifact?
answer: It is no longer carried by the Assassin, and is uncontrolled in the target's location. Any unit may pick it up normally (including the Assassin, if it happens to be in that location).

question: Does the Assassin lose Stealth if it uses its ability?
answer: Yes. It's an activated special ability, so Stealth is lost per the normal Stealth rules.

question: Can this be summoned to an inhospitable location (e.g. underground) and die, but still have a chance to use its genesis ability first?
answer: No. You cannot choose to summon a minion underground, underwater, or in the void unless it has the appropriate ability.

question: The term 'summon' means 'enter the realm.' So, does that mean I can play this minion for free?
answer: No. This effect simply provides additional locations where you may summon this minion.

question: Does the 'adjacent Water site' need to be in the same region as the caster?
answer: No. Because the Water site is not targeted, and because the card text uses 'site' instead of 'location,' the site does not need to be in the same region as the caster.

question: Can I cast this spell without a target just to draw a card?
answer: No. To cast a spell, you must specify all targets.

question: Does the target need to be in the same region as the caster?
answer: No. Normally the answer is yes, but the card text 'above or ((below))' means that normal targeting restrictions are ignored, and the caster can be in any region (surface, underground, underwater, or in the void). As long as there is an adjacent Water site to the caster and a minion occupying that water site, it will get pulled to the caster's location.

question: What does 'one at a time' mean?
answer: Resolve the first bolt (including any deathrite or other 'kills' abilities), then resolve the next one, then resolve the 3rd one. Each bolt must go in the same direction.

question: Are these family cards of Castle Servants, Common Cottagers, Blacksmith Family, and Fisherman's Family considered Air, Earth, Fire, and Water spells, respectively?
answer: Yes. You can see the spell's colored frame matches those elements, so Castle Servants is an Air spell, Common Cottagers is an Earth spell, Blacksmith Family is a Fire spell, and Fisherman's Family is a Water Spell.

question: If damage is prevented, do I still heal?
answer: No. Flagellant must actually take 1 or more damage for you to heal.

question: If Flagellant takes 5 damage, do I heal more than 1?
answer: No, just 1. But if Flagellant took 1 damage separately five times, e.g. Abyssal Assault or Arcane Barrage, you would heal 5.

question: Can the grid pattern be flipped horizontally?
answer: Yes. You pick the leftmost or rightmost column, and that is where the Flame Wave starts.

question: Can the grid pattern be rotated 90 degrees?
answer: No.

question: Is the projectile considered fire damage?
answer: Yes.

question: If the attack damage was increased or decreased, does the splash damage include the change?
answer: Yes. For example, Critical Strike will splash double damage.

question: If a unit has two Flaming Swords, do they each splash damage?
answer: Yes. Have fun dual wielding!

question: Is the splash damage a strike?
answer: No. It's damage done by the sword artifact.

question: Does the splash damage occur whenever the unit strikes?
answer: Yes. For example, that includes Grapple Shot or other strikes, not just attacks from the Move and Attack basic ability.

question: If the struck unit isn't an enemy, is any damage splashed?
answer: No. If there's no 'struck unit,' then it has no location. Also, there are no 'other enemies' when there's no enemy initially. See '((enemy))' in the codex.

question: If the Battlemage with a Flaming Sword attacks one enemy, and then another enemy dies as a result of the Flaming Sword, does the Battlemage get to draw a card?
answer: Yes. An attack was made, and then a minion was killed. As long as your attacking unit used the Move and Attack ability and then got kill credit, this ability triggers.

question: Do the locations need to be in the same region?
answer: No. The squares merely need to be a Knight's move apart. Teleportation ignores normal movement restrictions.

question: How do Drought and Flood interact?
answer: See '((Example - Flood vs. Drought))' in the codex.

question: Can Floodplain still flood a site affected by Drought?
answer: Yes. See '((Example - Flood vs. Drought))' in the codex.

question: Can I use Floodplain before Maelström triggers?
answer: No. Floodplain is an activated ability, which can only be activated during your Main Phase.

question: Can my Free City be struck by opposing units, and if so, will it take damage?
answer: Yes, it can be struck, and any strike damage to your Free City will cause your avatar to ))lose(( the same amount of life.

question: How do the strikes work?
answer: Normally, only units can strike, but card text allows the Free City site to strike as if it were a unit with 3 power.

question: Can Free City die?
answer: It's striking as if it were a unit, but it's still a site. Therefore, it won't die due to damage. It can still be destroyed by a specific destruction effect (e.g. Sinkhole), but it won't die due to taking damage.

question: When can it attack?
answer: Free City's ability is a passive ability that gives it the option to attack and defend 'normally' once per turn, as if it were a 3 power unit (while actually remaining a site). Therefore, it can only attack on your turn, and defend (presumably on your opponent's turn) when a unit or Free City itself is attacked by an enemy unit occupying Free City. If Free City would somehow have the chance to both attack AND defend on your turn, it can only do one.

question: What can it attack?
answer: The key word is 'here.' Clearly burrowed units are 'here.' Airborne and Stealthed units are also 'here.' But, to attack Airborne or Stealth, a unit needs some special ability (e.g. Airborne, Ranged, etc.) Since Free City doesn't have those abilities, it can't actually target Airborne or Stealthed units with an attack.

question: How does the attack work?
answer: Since the ability to attack is granted by a card effect and not a basic ability, no tapping is needed, but it's still an attack. Therefore, players may declare defenders for the attack normally.

question: Can Free City attack the turn it enters play?
answer: Yes, because only minions are subject to summoning sickness.

question: If an oversized unit occupies Free City while it attacks a different site, can Free City defend against that attack?
answer: No, since the attack is not happening on Free City.

question: Can Frontier Settlers play a site that isn't adjacent to your other sites?
answer: Yes.

question: When I play an Earth site using the second ability, do I also place a rubble in an adjacent void?
answer: No. You only place a rubble if you play an Earth site using the first ability.

question: When I play an Earth site using the first ability, where does the rubble appear?
answer: The rubble must be placed adjacent to your Geomancer. If there's no void adjacent to your Geomancer, then no rubble is placed.

question: Does Mirror Realm (copying an earth site) or Valley of Delight (choosing earth) count for Geomancer's first ability?
answer: Yes. Mirror ))Realm(( works because it applies as it enters the realm. Valley of Delight works because the Genesis effect of the site interrupts the resolution of the Geomancer's ability; when the second part of Geomancer's ability actually resolves and looks at the site, the site is indeed an earth (E) site. See '((Splitting Events on the Storyline))' for more details on Valley of Delight interaction, analogous to the Tawny example and splitting the Druid's ability.

question: If I teleport my Ghost Ship from the void to a site, does its ability trigger?
answer: Yes.

question: If I summon a Spirit from my opponent's cemetery, do I control it?
answer: Yes. (And as usual for an explicit summon effect, you don't need threshold and you don't pay mana.)

question: Will it fight units that are Airborne or Stealthed?
answer: Yes. This isn't an attack (which has targeting restrictions), but actually a fight (which simply specifies who fights based on card text).

question: What path can I choose when resolving this ability?
answer: See ((Moving to a Specific Location Via a Special Ability or Magic)) in the Codex.

question: Will it fight your own units?
answer: Yes.

question: Does 'enters' include minions that are summoned?
answer: Yes.

question: If a unit moves within the same site (e.g. surface to underwater, or underwater to surface), does Shark trigger?
answer: No, since the unit is not entering or moving between different sites.

question: What happens if I summon my minion with Genesis into my opponent's Shark's body of water?
answer: See the storyline codex entry for details.

question: Can the Shark's path include movement from surface to underwater, or underwater to surface, if needed?
answer: Yes, as long as the path specified is the fewest steps possible to the target.

question: If a Shark moves through a Silence aura, what happens?
answer: The movement and fight still occur. The specific resolution is: Unit enters the water site, Shark's ability triggers. You specify the movement steps to reach the target, and they all go on the Storyline. Shark starts moving. It enters the Silence aura, but the effects of the ability are still on the Storyline and aren't removed, so they continue resolving normally.

question: A minion with Gilded Aegis is on a site chosen for Scorched Earth. The Aegis and the minion are being destroyed simultaneously. Does the Aegis have a chance to save the minion before it's destroyed?
answer: Yes.

question: If forcefully burrowed without burrowing, will a unit with Gilded Aegis still die?
answer: Yes.

question: Is this effect limited to once per turn?
answer: Nope! You may use it as many times as you want in a turn, if you meet the threshold requirement. Of course, in Constructed play, you'll be limited to four, since you can have at most four Horrible Hybrids in your collection.

question: If I have Crusade or House Arn Bannermen affecting my Gnome Hollows, may I summon a 2-power minion there?
answer: Yes. It's first summoned (enters the realm), then ongoing effects are applied (e.g. Crusade).

question: If Megamoeba starts at 2 power, can it move into Gnome Hollows (thus getting to 3 power)?
answer: Yes. First, Megamoeba enters, then it grows in power immediately after entering.

question: If the most direct path is blocked (Gnome Hollows, Wall of Ice) will the grappling unit move around those obstacles to reach its target?
answer: No. 'Dragged' is equivalent to 'Pull,' and 'Pull' requires each location entered to be closer to the destination. Making any detours wouldn't be getting closer to the Avatar, so the unit cannot take that path.

question: How do I resolve this effect?
answer: Deal face up to your back row one at a time. Then, shuffle any non-minions and put them on the bottom of your deck. Now all the minions are summoned simultaneously; resolve any effects of those minions being summoned, e.g. genesis effects. Finally, check to see if you're at Death's Door now, and if so, all the summoned minions gain Charge.

question: The alpha and beta text is different, which should I use?
answer: The Beta text is correct.

question: Do I resolve all the steps at once, or can effects (e.g. Bottomless Pit) interrupt the movement?
answer: See the storyline codex entry for details.

question: Can a disabled unit Grapple Shot?
answer: No, since it would be shooting a projectile, and disabled units can't do that.

question: If I Grapple Shot a minion with Submerge through an area affected by Mariner's Curse, what happens?
answer: When the Grapple Shot projectile hits the unit, the game adds specific movement steps for the ally to the Storyline: Move A (surface) -> B (surface), Move B (surface) -> C (surface). Then, we start resolving those steps. If Mariner's Curse is on site B, once the unit being dragged reaches site B, it will be submerged, and live. Then the game tries to resolve Move B (surface) -> C (surface), which fails, since the unit isn't on the surface of site B anymore. Thus, there's no strike from Grapple Shot since it didn't reach the hit unit's location.

question: If the most direct path is blocked (Gnome Hollows, Wall of Ice) will the grappling unit move around those obstacles to reach its target?
answer: No. 'Dragged' is equivalent to 'Pull,' and 'Pull' requires each location entered to be closer to the destination. Making any detours wouldn't be getting closer to the Avatar, so the unit cannot take that path.

question: How does Drought interact with Great Old One?
answer: These are both passive effects, so whichever was played last takes precedence.

question: What does it actually mean to permanently flood the realm, including voids?.
answer: All sites (including rubble) are flooded for the rest of the game, even sites that enter the realm later.

question: The foil and non-foil beta cards have different text. Which is correct?
answer: The non-foil beta text is correct. You may use a foil beta Great Wall in tournament play (or the alpha version), but it must be played with the non-foil beta text; ensure your opponent knows the proper text when it's played.

question: Does this stop all kinds of movement through the top border (e.g. Grapple Shot), or just the Move and Attack basic ability?
answer: The Great Wall will stop most kinds of movement on the surface, with a few notable exceptions. Teleportation doesn't cross borders, and if a unit 'moves as if adjacent' (e.g. Waypoint Portal), that also doesn't cross borders. Finally airborne units can fly over the wall as they are not moving 'on the ground.'

question: The alpha and beta text is different, which should I use?
answer: The beta text is correct.

question: How do I resolve this ability?
answer: Rasputin must be in your cemetery to use this ability. Then, choose the Evil ally you will banish, which may be anywhere and not limited to your own sites. Since Banishing is the cost of the activated ability, resolve the whole activated ability before actually banishing the minion. (This is analogous to the '((Sacrifice))' rules.) Rasputin gains the printed power and abilities of the ally. Resolve Genesis abilities and any 'enter the realm' abilities. Finally, the Banished ally is actually removed from the realm. (Place it under Rasputin as a reminder of the current effect.)

question: How does this ability work?
answer: When Reaper kills a minion, the minion is banished instead of dying. In addition, any copies of that minion in play (regardless of who controls them) are also banished. Finally, you search the owner's library of the minion that was killed (and only that player).

question: If a unit is carrying the animated artifact, who retains control?
answer: When the artifact is animated, it becomes a minion, and thus cannot be carried. The controller of Grösse Poltergeist gets control.

question: If the unit carrying the animated artifact can also carry minions, who retains control?
answer: Grösse Poltergeist says you gain control, but the game rules say that anyone carrying the artifact gains control. Grösse Poltergiest takes precedence due to the golden rule, and the controller of Grösse Poltergeist gets control.

question: Can you 'fly to' a minion already sharing your location?
answer: No, that's not 'flying to.' Summon the Guardian Angel to a different location!

question: What path can I choose when resolving this ability?
answer: See ((Moving to a Specific Location Via a Special Ability or Magic)) in the Codex.

question: Can it target a unit in a different region?
answer: No. Targeting (by default) requires the source and the target to be in the same region.

question: Does the target minion use its enhanced move abilities?
answer: Yes. When an effect has a unit 'take steps,' it uses its enhanced move abilities granted by keywords such Voidwalk, Burrowing, Submerge, and Airborne.

question: Does it tap the target minion? Can this movement be intercepted?
answer: No and no. This isn't the Move and Attack basic ability, which is what requires tapping and can be intercepted.

question: Consider the group of sites below. An oversized minion occupies 1-2-4-5. Guile Sirens is #5. Can the oversized minion be pulled in any way?
answer: Yes. When pulling or pushing an oversized unit, choose a single location the oversized unit occupies (and meets the requirement of the effect), and push/pull from there. So, you could choose Site 2: Oversized minion is pulled South, and ends up at 4-5-7-8. OR, choose Site 4: Oversized minion is pulled East, and ends up at 2-3-5-6. OR, choose Site 5: Oversized minion isn't pulled at all.

question: Is the ability mandatory?
answer: Yes. It doesn't use the word 'may.'

question: Does Harbinger's ability combo with other effects that allow you to cast minions, e.g. Elder Ruins, Troubled Town, Peculiar Port, etc.?
answer: Yes! It's effectively a passive ability that can be used whenever you cast a spell on your turn. The golden rule, baby!

question: When I determine my three random squares, what if I roll doubles or triples?
answer: Reroll any duplicated results until you have three ))unique(( squares.

question: What path can I choose when resolving this ability?
answer: See ((Moving to a Specific Location Via a Special Ability or Magic)) in the Codex.

question: Does this apply if my opponent is searching my deck as well?
answer: Yes! Any time your opponent is searching their deck or your deck, they only search the top three cards.

question: What if my Headless Haunt tries to teleport into an illegal location? (e.g. Gnome Hollows)
answer: The teleport effect fails, and it remains where it was.

question: What does 'shuffle if needed' mean?
answer: If you searched your spellbook, shuffle it. If you end up summoning a beast from your hand, you may still have searched your spellbook if you wanted.

question: If my minion gains charge from the Horn to Move and Attack and then leaves the Horn's range, can it finish the attack?
answer: Yes, as the minion has already tapped, the rest of the Move and Attack will resolve. Once a charge has been sounded in the heat of battle, there's no stopping it!

question: How do I resolve this effect?
answer: Deal face up, one at a time. Then, draw the voidwalk minions and Monsters, and banish the rest. No minions actually 'enter' the realm with this effect.

question: If Ice Lance doesn't hit anything at the first location where the projectile appears, and then hits something at the 2nd location, how much damage does it do at that 2nd location?
answer: 2 damage at the 2nd location. Ice Lance's damage decreases based on locations the projectile enters, not based on how many things it hits or doesn't hit.

question: What is a fire card?
answer: Fire sites and fire spells are fire cards. See the 'element' codex entry for more details.

question: What is fire damage?
answer: Damage from a fire card.

question: If I play a Village on my opponent's turn via Imperial Road, can I pay 1 mana to summon a Foot Soldier?
answer: The genesis effect triggers, but you don't have any mana available on your opponent's turn, so no.

question: Can Imposter wear masks of Avatars with pre-game or setup abilities, and if so, what happens?
answer: Yes, you can wear masks of those avatars, and you simply ignore their pre-game or setup abilities since the game has already started by the time you put on the mask. For example: You can use [[Pathfinder]]'s ability even though your atlas has duplicate sites. You don't get to pick a Unique Dragon as [[Dragonlord]]. (Probably not a good choice of masks.) You don't roll for summoning portals as [[Harbinger]]. (Probably not a good choice of masks.) Your decks and card sleeves remain as-is for [[Magician]].  (Probably not a good choice of masks.)

question: What rarity are Avatars for purposes of including them in my collection?
answer: Consider Avatars unique for purposes of including them in your collection.

question: What happens if I impersonate the Druid and then use the ability to flip?
answer: You will summon Bruin, flip, ... and then immediately lose the game because you no longer have an Avatar in play! Maybe don't include Druid in your collection?

question: If my Infiltrated unit attacks my opponent's undefended site, do I retain control of it?
answer: No. Once the infiltrated minion no longer has stealth, you ))lose(( control of it.

question: When does the enemy avatar have the opportunity to pay life?
answer: Immediately after the strike, before deathrites resolve. For example, if your strike puts them to 2 or less life, they will not be able to pay 3 life.

question: What happens if I strike for 0 damage?
answer: A strike for zero damage is still considered a strike, so it will still trigger Interrogator's ability.

question: Normally pull effects can't cross regional boundaries. Can I actually pull the target minion into the void?
answer: Yes, obviously!

question: Can I target a burrowed minion or a voidwalk minion?
answer: Not unless you have a burrowed spellcaster or a spellcaster in the void. Since the effect uses the word 'target,' the spellcaster must be in the same region as the target. (There are four regions: surface, underground, underwater, void.)

question: Does it turn into a Monster minion?
answer: Yes. It becomes a minion with the Monster type, and no longer a site.

question: If the flooded Rubble gets replaced with a site, is the new site also flooded?
answer: No.

question: When it awakens, is it summoning sick?
answer: Assuming it was in play prior to the turn it awakened, it is not summoning sick (since it was already under your control prior to this turn).

question: Is the ability optional?
answer: Yes. It is an activated ability with no cost and a requirement of 8 water threshold. Like all activated abilities, you can only activate it during your Main Phase when nothing else is happening, but you are not required to activate it.

question: Does it continue to provide water affinity after it transforms into a Monster?
answer: Yes. The flooded rubble does not provide any affinity to you (since you don't control it), but the Island Leviathan itself does provide affinity, since that's aligned with the golden rule. Obviously if the Monster dies, then you lose that affinity.

question: Is Jack the Ripper a Monster as well as a Mortal?
answer: Yes! The inclusion of the capitalized 'Monstrous' in his typeline makes him a Monster (and thus Evil).

question: The term 'summon' means 'enter the realm.' So, does that mean I can play minions here for free?
answer: No. This effect simply provides additional locations where you may summon your fire minions.

question: When exactly do the minions fight?
answer: After both units have taken their step they will fight from their new locations. If either doesn't move, they haven't passed each other and therefore no joust takes place.

question: How do I 'archive the state of the realm' ?
answer: Take a snapshot of the cards in the realm. Players should literally take a picture of it on their phone! If you include this card in your deck, you should be prepared to take a picture during the game. Make additional notes as needed to track things like whether a unit has used its Pick Up and Drop ability for the turn, the controller of a Mesmerized minion, or if there's an ongoing effect on a minion like ))Power(( of Flight. Players are expected to make additional notes as needed to be able to recreate the state of those cards, if a picture alone is insufficient.

question: When I 'archive the state of the realm,' does that include players' life totals?
answer: No. Players' life totals will not revert when Kairos's deathrite resolves.

question: When I 'archive the state of the realm,' does that include cards outside the realm?
answer: No! It does not include any other zone. The thing to focus on are literally the state of cards in the realm right now.

question: Do I archive global effects like Critical Strike?
answer: No, since it's not an 'archived card,' but instead an ongoing effect that hasn't yet been applied. The test for inclusion in the archive is if the effect is currently applying to a card in the realm. E.g. Whether or not you've discarded a card for Wizard's Den would be included in the archive.

question: When a card is 'returned to its recorded state,' does it enter the realm?
answer: No, it is not entering the realm. Genesis, Stealth, Lance, etc. will not trigger and sites do not generate mana.

question: How do I 'return all archived cards to their recorded state' ?
answer: Players should look at the picture they took, then return each card to where it was before, though banished cards can never be returned; sometimes knowledge is truly lost. Once Kairos enters the realm, cards will be tracked across zones solely for the purpose of his deathrite. He's that good of a librarian! If tracking a card across zones is not possible due to hidden information, e.g. shuffled into your deck, then the player may return the card from any zone (but never from banished).

question: When we 'return all archived cards to their recorded state,' do all changes happen simultaneously?
answer: Yes.

question: When a card is 'returned to its recorded state,' does it move or enter the location?
answer: No. It does not enter the location; simply place it wherever the picture shows. This is not movement. It's like we're rewinding time, not actually moving cards around.

question: Let's say the realm is archived, then I cast an artifact into my unit's hands, then my unit moves. Then Kairos dies. Does my unit bring its carried artifact when it returns to its recorded state?
answer: No! Carried artifacts do move with their bearer whenever their bearer moves, but when you 'return to its recorded state,' that's not considered movement! It's a one-of-a-kind direct placement effect. Therefore, the artifact gets left behind, wherever it is. It's like we're rewinding time, not actually moving cards around.

question: When archived cards are returned to the realm, does that include tokens that were archived?
answer: Yes! If a token was in the realm and archived, it will return to its recorded state when Kairos dies. If the token left the realm (and was thus banished), the token still returns to its recorded state, because there are always unlimited copies of tokens available to the players.

question: When we 'return all archived cards to their recorded state,' do all non-archived cards (e.g. cards that entered the realm after Kairos) remain unchanged?
answer: Yes. They remain where they are, though if a recently ))played(( or ))moved(( site is in the way of a site that's returning to its recorded state, the site that's in the way will get banished! See below for more examples and details.

question: When we 'return all archived cards to their recorded state,' what if non-archived sites are in the way?
answer: The site that's in the way gets banished! For example, the realm is archived, then Cloud City moves, then a Lone Tower site fills in the square where Cloud City was archived. Then Kairos dies. The Lone Tower is banished and Cloud City returns to its recorded state!

question: What about Earthquake or Rubble?
answer: If Kairos archived the realm with Rubble in it, then Rubble will replace whatever sites are there when cards return to their recorded state, banishing any sites in the way! For Earthquake, imagine the following sequence: The realm is archived with sites on squares 3, 8, and 9. Then, a Lone Tower is played on square 4. Earthquake gets played, rearranging sites. Kairos dies. The sites now return to their recorded state. That means the sites that were originally on squares 3, 8, and 9 go back to where they were, all simultaneously. The Lone Tower does not change squares because it was not an archived card. If it's now in the way and in square 3, 8, or 9, it will get banished by the site that's returning there. Don't mess with the Archivist!

question: Can you give a complicated Kairos example?
answer: Enjoy this one: I have an Kettletop Leprechaun on Gnome Hollows in square 8. You have a Cloud Spirit on Cloud City in square 3. The realm gets archived. Then: Cloud City moves to square 9 and you summon Bluecap Knockers there. I cast a Grim Guisarme into the hands of my Leprechaun, who moves to square 9. I cast a House Arn Bannerman into the Gnome Hollows. Then, Kairos dies. All of the following happen simultaneously: My Kettletop Leprechaun returns to square 8; even though it's a Gnome Hollows and the Leprechaun has 3 power due to the House Arn Bannerman, remember that the 'return' effect is not movement and is not considered 'entering.' The Grim Guisarme is not an archived card, and it remains where it is on square 9. Carried artifacts move whenever their bearer moves, but returning is not a movement effect, so the artifact doesn't automatically come with the Leprechaun. The Cloud Spirit and Cloud City return to square 3; this is not movement, and thus Bluecap Knockers does not prevent it. The Bluecap Knockers find themselves in the void and are banished. There is a Grim Guisarme in the void on square 9 now. Had there been a site on square 3, it would have been banished as Cloud City returned to that square. When in doubt, always apply the Golden Rule, but especially with Kairos!

question: What if there are multiple Kairos's in play?
answer: Whenever a new Kairos archives the realm, that becomes the most recent snapshot for all Kairos deathrite effects. That is, there is only a single archive of the realm at a time. Archivists unite!

question: What if Kairos dies on The Geistwood?
answer: Since the deathrite effect and genesis effect will be triggered simultaneously, you may order them as you wish. If you resolve the printed deathrite first, archived cards will return to their recorded state, then the printed genesis effect will not resolve, since Kairos is banished. If you resolve the printed genesis first (as a deathrite due to The Geistwood), the realm will be archived, and then when the printed deathrite resolves, it would return to that very recently archived state, and Kairos would be banished.

question: Can your avatar end up in the void after Kairos dies, and if so, what happens?
